Award.AwardTitle: Science, Mathematics, and Technology Scholars - Increasing Diversity through Mentoring

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The goal of this project is to construct an academic support program that meets the needs of financially disadvantaged students. Over the four-year grant period, 30 need-based scholarships are provided to qualified science, mathematics, and technology students at Louisiana State University. The students are participating in a variety of activities, including academic advising and mentoring, Individual Development Plans, academic and professional development activities, academic enhancement program, and research training activities provided by the faculty mentors in the sciences and math disciplines. The project increases the number of well-prepared undergraduates, including woman and minorities, entering graduate school or industry. The project also promotes inter-cultural participation among non-minority and minority students and faculty members.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Office of Strategic Initiatives (OSI) at Louisiana State University (LSU) hosted a “Science, Mathematics, and Technology Scholars - Increasing Diversity through Mentoring” S-STEM program.  The S-STEM Program served academically talented Science and Mathematics majors with a financial need. The objectives of this project are to retain these students through the incorporation of student support and mentoring programs that enhance their educational experiences. The Office of Strategic Initiatives, the Center for Academic Success, and faculty members throughout the science and math disciplines provided active mentoring and academic assistance for the scholars to maximize their chances for academic success.  In addition, the Scholars were provided with various enhancement opportunities such as mentoring and tutoring high school students, peer tutoring, and joining student professional organizations.  The S-STEM Program promoted diversity in all areas including ethnicity, gender, and discipline.

In total, 112 students were served, of which 61% were women and 49% were from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups. Eighty-four percent (84%) of LSU S-STEM scholars completed B.S. degrees in STEM disciplines. Underrepresented students and women graduated at comparable rates (83% and 85%), respectively. Another 9% completed B.S. degrees in non-STEM areas.  While, primary emphasis was focused on their experiences at LSU, additional initiatives were employed to prepare students for matriculation into post-baccalaureate programs. As a result, to date, forty-six percent (46%) of S-STEM Scholars served have either completed or are pursuing post-baccalaureate degrees, including 10% at the doctoral level.  

 


Last Modified: 05/02/2017
Modified by: Gloria A Thomas

The S-STEM Program served academically talented Science and Mathematics majors with a financial need. The objectives of this project are to retain these students through the incorporation of student support and mentoring programs that enhance their educational experiences. The Office of Strategic Initiatives, the Center for Academic Success, and faculty members throughout the science and math disciplines provided active mentoring and academic assistance for the scholars to maximize their chances for academic success. In addition, the Scholars were provided with various enhancement opportunities such as mentoring and tutoring high school students, peer tutoring, and joining student professional organizations. The S-STEM Program promoted diversity in all areas including ethnicity, gender, and discipline. In total, 112 students were served, of which 61% were women and 49% were from underrepresented racial and ethnic groups. Eighty-four percent (84%) of LSU S-STEM scholars completed B.S. degrees in STEM disciplines. Underrepresented students and women graduated at comparable rates (83% and 85%), respectively. Another 9% completed B.S. degrees in non-STEM areas. While, primary emphasis was focused on their experiences at LSU, additional initiatives were employed to prepare students for matriculation into post-baccalaureate programs. As a result, to date, forty-six percent (46%) of S-STEM Scholars served have either completed or are pursuing post-baccalaureate degrees, including 10% at the doctoral level.
